ResponsesInList.Title: Bug in Moodle Book module: Deleting a chapter deletes subchapters
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I wanted to share a frustrating experience I encountered with the Moodle Book module and see if anyone has suggestions or if this can be improved in future updates. (4.5.5 version) Here’s what happened: I created a new chapter in an existing Book. Moodle automatically assigned subchapters of a different chapter as subchapters of this new chapter. I did not intend for this hierarchical change. I then deleted the new chapter, thinking only the new chapter would be removed. All the subchapters were deleted as well, without any warning or prompt. This is extremely problematic because: The UI does not make the change of the parent-child relationship obvious. Deleting a single chapter can silently remove a lot of content. There is no confirmation dialogue that clearly says “this will also delete subchapters.” Moodle does not have a undo for this and the recycle bin do not cover book chapters at all Recommendations: We should have a warning when deleting chapters, especially if that have subchapters. Chapters should create entries in the recycle bin This bug (or UX issue) feels super annoying and could easily cause loss of content for other instructors as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to reset the 'view' condition of a page?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would assign each cohort of students into a separate group to facilitate keeping track using "Activity completion". In a simple case, there may be two groups: "Current" and "Past". Amendment pages should be created as separate "Page" resources so that they are trackable. The amendment Pages are for the "Past" group and should be conditionally displayed to that group only. If there are amendments in "Book" resources, then in order to achieve maximum clarity for current students, I would recommend that you update the material in the book, but also create a new amendment "Page" with the revised information for the "Past" group. Each new amendment should be a separate new Page. If a new amendment replaces a previous amendment, use the date condition to hide the old amendment page from students. That way you can track completion of each amendment separate, and avoid resetting any completions. Label your amendment pages wisely, so you can easily understand the tracking data.

ResponsesInList.Title: We want to make a small number of our books printable for our students

If you enable/disable a permission at the site level (by editing the student role), I *think* this change at the site-level role-editing does force it's way down into all the courses? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: We want to make a small number of our books printable for our students

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: We want to make a small number of our books printable for our students
ResponsesInList.Text: Edit the Student role at the Site Level (Users - Permissions - Define Roles) and ensure Print Book is not an enabled permission. Then in each specific Book activity, edit the permissions (I think by selecting "Permissions" in the "More Menu" of newer Moodle versions, and in older Moodle versions you select "Assign roles" or "locally assigned roles" in the admin block and then switching over to "Permissions") and add the Student role next to the capability to Print Book. The Override permissions Docs walks through this with some images/examples

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Content Search in Block Activity
ResponsesInList.Text: You could use the Microsoft Word File Import/Export (Book) plugin to export the book into Word, and then quickly search in Word to find occurrences of the terms you want to change. Each chapter in the book is converted to a "Heading 1" style in Word, so you can  then go back into the corresponding chapter in the book inside Moodle, and edit it. You would have to repeat this process for each book though. If you have access to Microsoft OneDrive, it has an excellent text search facility, so if you exported all of your books into Word files in a OneDrive folder, you can search for the terms across all books at once. If this is a regular occurrence, a better approach would be enable and configure the Global search facility on the Moodle site, but this requires significant resources. This would allow you search for terms across all content,  whether in books or elsewhere, directly within Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Problem with exporting book using Wordimport plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: I get a HTTP ERROR 500 when I try to export a book to Word. It works if I export a chapter, but not a book. I installed the plugin via the install plugins from the Moodle plugins directory. Can anyone please assist? Marinda

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with exporting book using Wordimport plugin
ResponsesInList.Text:
I suspect that some of the HTML markup inside your book contains invalid XHTML .
The export facility tries to fix up bad markup by running the content through a HTMLTidy process, but it can fail with particularly awkward content. If text was copied from Word and pasted into a book a long time ago, for example (before the Atto
editor cleaned up this content automatically), then this could happen. There are a number of steps you can take to get around this. 1. Open each chapter in the Atto text editor and save it again. Atto will clean up the content when it saves it. 2. If that doesn't fix it, export each chapter individually and identify the one causing the problem. Open that chapter in the Atto editor, go to raw HTML view (expand the first icon in the Atto toolbar (a down-arrow), and then click the last icon
to see the raw HTML ("</>")). Copy and paste the HTML text into an online HTML Tidy website like https://htmltidy.net/ . This might do a better job cleaning it up. 3. If neither works, try installing a plugin to export (and import the book to an ePub (cf. https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=category&id=56 ). Then export to ePub, which should ensure the output is valid XHTML . Re-import it into a different book, and export that book into Word format.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with Import chapters by WOrd Import plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a bug in the conversion software. The plugin extracts the text from the "Heading 1" (chapters) and "Heading 2" (subchapters) styles in Word in order to populate the Table of Contents. However, it expects only plain text, without any extra formatting like bold or italic. If there is any extra formatting, it fails, and the name of the temporary generated intermediate HTML file is used instead. To fix it, go to the relevant heading in Word, select all the text, and press <Ctrl>+<Space> to clear any formatting, then re-import it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Editing bullets and numbers - Microsoft Word File Import/Export (Book)
ResponsesInList.Text: <Ctrl>+<Shift>+L is already mapped to create the "List Bullet" style by default in Word. <Ctrl>+<Shift>+S is already mapped to open the "Apply Styles" panel, so I don't recommend overriding it. I recommend using the moodleBookStartup.dotm Word template I created, that has a set of commands and keyboard shortcuts defined to speed up editing (cf. http://www.moodle2word.net/mod/resource/view.php?id=44 ). In this template, <Ctrl>+8 applies the List Bullet style, and <Ctrl>+9 the List Number style. The screenshot below shows the custom Ribbon and the various built-in and custom styles named so that its easier to use. Shortcuts are displayed when you mouse over a style name. You need to install the template in your Word Startup folder (usually something like C:\Documents and Settings\ <your_account>\ Application Data\Microsoft\Word\Startup\ ) . See http://www.moodle2word.net/mod/page/view.php?id=16 for instructions on how to do this. This template contains VBA macros, and in some cases, Windows 10 may warn that they contain viruses. They don't, but the digital signature is now out-of-date too, so it makes it more awkward to install. I also recommend using a standard Word style template to apply the same formatting to all documents made. The attached Word style template is one that I use. It does not contain any VBA macros, so you shouldn't have any trouble with it. It should be installed somewhere like C:\Documents and Settings\ <your_account>\ Application Data\Microsoft\Templates\ . You can also just assign your own preferred shortcuts, see instructions at How to Assign Keyboard Shortcuts to Styles in Microsoft Word .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allow users to rate each page in a book
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sa Ku, To rate any page in a book will require you to set up something to do it with. For instance, you could set up a, Questionnaire activity, with a rating scale question for each page of your book. You could also probably use the Feedback activity, with a similar set up. If you add pages to the book, you will have to "modify" your questionnaire or feedback activity to include rating for the new page(s). You could also probably use, Hot Question. With it, you can set up an entry for each book page and let students "Vote" for the page. You could also just let the students create the initial entry for each book page and then vote. With Hot Question, if you add a new book page, you can dynamically include it into Hot Question. Note: Since you are probably going to want to keep info about each page of the book in order in Hot Question, you can over ride the "Vote" order by setting "Teacher Priority" to control the order. Questionnaire and Feedback will require more direct work from the teacher to set up than that required by Hot Question. Personally, if you have a place for testing, I would try out all three, then adopt the "best" one. Oh, you might be able to do a rating with the Quiz activity, too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allow users to rate each page in a book
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sa Ku, So far as I know, you cannot add any other activities to a book. What you CAN do is create a link on a book page, that takes you to an activity. For instance, in your book on any given page, you could add a link that would go to an activity, such as Hot Question, to rate the page. The link could be set to open in a new window. In the description of the Hot Question, just in case, you could then have a link to take users back to the correct page of the book. I suspect, that whatever method you decide on, it will take a bit of extra work to set it up and get it going the way you want it to.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add icons in TOC
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi René, This is easy to do, and without having to modify the book table of contents code, if you can install plugins. The plugin you will need is the Generico filter. It comes with a sampling of included filter presets, one of which is, Font Awesome. Once you have the Generico filter installed, enabled it, set it to work for both Content and Headings, added it's toolbutton to Atto, go to Site administration > Plugins > Filters > Generico then open one of the empty templates, and Autofill template with a Preset > Font Awesome. To actually use it, edit a page in your Book. Since there is no toolbar for a chapter title, you will need to add the Generico Font Awesome template into the Content area first. Just pick a blank line, click the Generico toobutton, type the name of the font awesome icon you want to use into the icon line pop-up. Make changes as needed to the orientation, size and layout entries, then click insert. Generico will generate and add a line of text into the Content. Cut and paste that line of text into the Chapter title in front of your title text, then finish up by clicking, Save changes. Rinse and repeat as needed for other chapters. If you are going to use the same icon multiple times, it might be faster to make a page with all the ones you want so you can just copy and paste the generated line of text wherever you need it, without having to go through the steps of repetitively creating it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Book Export to Word Plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: I had a quick look at this, and it isn't obvious to me how to do this (and I'm the developer!). However, on reflection, I don't think this is a good idea anyway. The export to Word facility is really intended as a temporary facility to enable Teachers to do a once-off export of a Moodle Book to Microsoft Word, so that they can edit it in Word. It is not intended for Students to treat it as a complete and true copy of the Book content. For example, images are not exported in a way that is directly visible to them. If a Teacher wants to make a printable version of a Book available, then I recommend that they export the Book to Word, prepare it (format it with appropriate headers and footers, re-instate images, etc.), and finally save the Word document as a PDF file, and upload that as a separate file beside the Book. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL keywords in a Book page can never be saved
ResponsesInList.Text: These issues are often as the result of a WAF (web application firewall) or Apache mod_security, which is obviously external to Moodle. This software is looking for keywords such as SELECT, UPDATE, DELETE (and many other types of attack) which can be used by attackers, and when detected will block the request reaching the destination server. Are you able to check with your IT department or server administrators to see if they have a system such as this in place? This is the most likely explanation for the problem IMO .

ResponsesInList.Text: Glad that works For future reference though, with the previous settings, if people could still see the activity grayed out - it means the "eye" in the restrict access settings was open rather than shut. If the eye is OPEN the students who do not meet that part of the condition will see the activity but it will be greyed out and have information about why they can't access it yet. If the eye is SHUT then students who do not meet that part of the condition will not see the activity at all. See https://docs.moodle.org/32/en/Restrict_access_settings#Hiding_the_conditions for info and screenshots.

ResponsesInList.Title: Early results of analysing use of the Book module at a University
ResponsesInList.Text: G'day All, Last week I gave a presentation at the Australian Moodlemoot titled "How and why do people use the Moodle Book module" . The presentation shared some early explorations of how the courses, learners and teachers at one Australian University used the Moodle Book from 2012 through 2015. I'm sharing here in case some of the findings might interest others. I'm also interested in hearing from folk at other institutions who have any insights into whether these findings are similar or very different. This blog post gives an overview of some of more interesting findings, including links to interactive graphs of the data. In summary, Only very small percentages of students tend to read every chapter in most books. Courses using the Book module tend to have large enrollments. Surprisingly, until recently they also tended to have fewer online only students than is common at the university. The median number of Book resource per course was 3 and the median number of chapters per Book was 4 (though there were extremes - 80 books, 100 chapters, over 74,000 words). Almost no-one is using the import chapters functionality David.

ResponsesInList.Title: Svar: Re: Svar: Re: Books, books, books - Lucimoo ebook import and export add-ons (EPUB 2 and 3)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the write-up, David. I will let Ordbrand know and we will see what can be done. Students have a number of off-line ebook reader tools to choose from, iBook on the iPad or iPhone, FBReader on Android, Lucifox on PCs with Firefox to name a few. EPUB is the standard vendor neutral format chosen by the international publishing organizations for digital publications, see the International Digital Publishing Forum, http://idpf.org/ , and it is supported by a large number of publishers and tool creators. Publishing is often done to a number of formats at once. Dealing with conversion is easier if the document is well structured and according to format specifications, i.e. it helps to be a bit strict, but when used one should strive to make it less obvious. EPUBs reuse existing web standards , adding a navigational spine to the content, which helps machine reading - think text-to-speech of a multimodal text in the correct order, and a packaging method - EPUBs are regular ZIP archive files, just with an extension of .epub rather than .zip. The current Lucimoo export tool allows only a single book to be exported. Another tool by Ordbrand is Luciwik EPUB/OPDS for Mediawiki (the software which runs Wikipedia). Luciwik lets you export a single article or to select several articles for export to EPUB. You can see an example in the left hand menu at http://far.no/index.php?title=Askeladden_og_de_gode_hjelperne . Luciwik also adds an Open Publication Distribution System book catalog to Mediawiki, allowing discovery of new books either from a web page or by adding the book catalogue feed to ebook readers like Lucifox or FBReader. Perhaps it will be possible to include this functionality in Lucimoo later. The Moodle Book module itself needs a bit of love, e.g. you cannot import a book directly by simply selecting an EPUB file as a resource file and have Moodle/Lucimoo import and display it. To make this happen requires changes to the Moodle Book module itself by its developers.

Users can be grouped and permissions and levels of editing or viewing can be added or removed for groups as well as individuals.  eg a group for tutors, a group for participants, a group for the examining board.  If a folder is made available to a group it becomes visible to those users, otherwise it remains hidden.  Same with documents. I found it all fairly straight forward to set up and think it will make a nice partner with Moodle. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I restrict access to a chapter in a book by password or completion of another activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: No. The book's access restrictions apply to the whole book. Each chapter can be manually, individually hidden, but that applies to all  students equally. However, you might find a Quiz even more useful, because you give different feedback to students who need/merit it. Add a question to make a place to record marks when you grade their hard-copy work. ResponsesInList.Title: Plugin to support importing Word documents into books
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I have just released a new plugin for books, which allows you import a Word file directly into a book. It imports any images embedded inside the Word file, and also automatically splits the file into chapters (and optionally subchapters) based on the heading styles used in Word. Heading 1 styles are considered chapter headings, and Heading 2 styles subchapter headings. It is now available for download on the plugins directory at Microsoft Word file import . ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Merging Books
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Donald, It can be done with just a little work. Let's say you have book A and book B and you want to wind up with the contents of both in Book A. Open book B. In it's administration block, click on Generate IMS CP . Save the generated file somewhere. Open book A. Click on Import chapter . On the new Import Chapter page, make sure Type is set on Each folder represents one chapter . Click on Choose a file . Browse to the location where you saved the file in step 3. Select the file and click Open . Click on Upload file. Back on the Import chapter page, click on Import . Click Continue . Book A should now have the contents of both A and B.

ResponsesInList.Title: Semi-Automated Powerpoint to Book Import - Free Macro
ResponsesInList.Text: I love sharing! I hope this helps someone (else) With a PowerPoint Macro, it is possible to save your slides and import them directly into Moodle Book using Import Chapter. Attached is the Macro Code, and below you can see step by step how to do it.  Note - This works on PowerPoint 2010 and should work for 2007 but not tested. 0. Load PowerPoint and the PPT file you want to Import into Moodle 1. Now, get Macros enabled on your PowerPoint (You need to see the Developer Tab). You might need admin support for this 2. Click on the Macros button, enter any Macro name (macro999), then click edit 3. Delete any code in the Macro already, and paste in the Macro in the attached file.  For safety sake, you should always check any foreign Macro to make sure it isn't doing anything weird - this one doesn't but check it anyway ps - never edit the macro using Word, or it will mess up the quotes.  Use notepad or notepad++ 4. Before you run the macro, make sure you select the Tools tab, and References.  Make sure you have Visual Basic for Applications, Microsoft PowerPoint nn.n Object Library, OLE Automation, and Microsoft Office nn.n Object Library enabled.  ps nn.n = the version number, so on my PowerPoint 2010 it is 14.0   - You only need to do steps 1 & 4 once per computer, but I think you need to do steps 2 & 3 for every presentation 5. Run the Macro - PowerPoint_ExportSlidesForMoodleBookImport 6. Select your pixel width (for example 600 or 700 or 800) 7. After the Macro completes running, there will be a folder in the same directory as the original PPT file, with the same name as the PPT file.  In that folder will be an HTML page and and .PNG image per slide.  If you just want the pictures, you are all set.  The HTML page is really only there because the Chapter Title comes from the PowerPoint slide title and Moodle needs that (saves you typing it in again!) 8. Create a Zip file, and add all the images and html sorted in Name order (that way the chapters all work fine). If you want any of the slides to be subchapters, rename the HTML files and add "_sub" to the end of the name. 9. Now go to Moodle, select the Book you want or create a new one, and select "Import Chapter", and upload the zip file.  If you get an error message saying there were no chapters to import, then you created the zip file but forgot to put the HTML and Image files into it. 10. You now have your book imported nicely.  You can import more chapters from another powerpoint file at the end if you want. Finally - should this be stored somewhere within Moodle that is more useful? If yes, please say where and I can include some screenshots to help (once a few people have tested this and ironed out any glitches) All the best!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedding quiz in book module
ResponsesInList.Text: The Book activity, to me, is a much needed strip down of the Lesson activity. I have a lot of experience with the Lesson activity, and have aired my frustrations multiple times. The fact is, no one on the development side of the coin is interested in pursuing any improvements in the Lesson module, and frankly I don't think they should. It's cluttered and clumsy and filled with oblique settings and behaviors. I wish I didn't have whole courses built out of them. I think a far superior option would be to have someone on the Book development side look into how to allow questions from the Question Bank to be inserted direclty into Books in the same manner that they're inserted into Quiz pages. Imagine that in addition to inserting a chapter or a subchapter, you could add a question page. When you click the "Add a question" button, you are given a variant on the "quiz building" screen, which would allow you to see the question bank. The page that would appear in the Book's content section would look like a page from a quiz. Maybe you could limit it so that there could only be 3 questions per page, or something, and allow the student to easily skip them should they want to (for reviewing materials later on, for instance). The singular advantage I see to this approach vs. how the Lesson behaves, is that you can easily create sets of questions that are usable for practice right beside sets of questions for assessment, INSIDE the Question Bank. As it is right now, questions inside Lessons are created in different formats, they live only in the Lesson itself, and have different settings compared to questions in Quizzes -- none of the improvements in the question engine from Moodle 2.0 are reflected in the Lesson activity. If I want to use the same type of question twice or change it later, I have to make it twice and change it twice (one in the QB, once in the Lesson). Imagine creating a set of 5 great assessment/quiz questions, and being able to duplicate all 5 and modify the numbers or phrasing. In 10 minutes you've made 5 great practice questions that can be embedded right beside the content that teaches the concept. I have never included Lessons in the Gradebook, and think it's not a feature I personally would ever use, so I don't necessarily see it as being useful in a Book version of the same functionality. For instance, it would seem very easy to implement only one set of what are currently quiz behaviors so that all questions in Books behave like, for instance, "Interactive with Multiple Tries" quiz questions, so that they're clearly interactive, multiple try, learning experiences, that the student can CHOOSE to engage with, without fear of point based retribution or risk. They could be skipped or included as part of the "Print book" functionality. I don't have the staff or the personal knowledge to implement this type of thing, but if it weren't for the Lesson activity's ability to pose interactive questions to students and the Book's lack of same, I would be using Books all of the time to present content. Thanks for listening to me rant!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedding quiz in book module
ResponsesInList.Text: Beatriz, Matt, Tim and Brendan At least four people now! I have read the above posts with great interest.  I have a couple of courses I've written in Moodle Book with the idea that students had an online textbook to study and support what we were doing at school.  The flexibility with media types I understood at the time to mean "interactive" but then I was new to teaching and learning and now realise that this is just a different mode of delivery of content. So when talking about interactive, we really mean that the student interacts with the knowledge and constructs meaning from it. When I read a text, I realise that I now ask my own questions during this process to make sense of what I am reading.  This is a skill that has taken me many years to develop but is made considerably more efficient by having the author or expert pose the questions as many do in any decent textbook. Formative assessment works well when a student then has immediate feedback on their constructs of meaning.  Moodle does this in various ways.  The book provides content, lessons provide a delivery of content through a web of choices (basic questions) and quizzes give the tutor the chance to elaborate excellent resources and foster a robust remote environment for guided learning. I suppose you could argue that what glues this all together then is the moodle course page itself and the learner can flip in and out of the activities . But wouldn't it be nice to have self assessment questions and reading quizzes embedded in the book activity so that you don't have to leave the book to take a quick test to see how well you're doing? Alternatively, is there not a simple way of bringing all these activities together in a sequential and seamless fashion so that the learner is unaware that they are flipping in and out and from one activity to another? Maybe that would be the solution - a navigation tool that reads a half chapter of the book, takes the user to a reading quiz and (wish list here!) depending on their score or confidence level, go back to another part pf the book or continue to the next book section. Moodle seems to be on the verge of creating a very powerful tool for learning.  All the bits seem to be there already ... they just need to be joined up in a way that the learner is unaware of or responsible for how they are taken between activities and can therefore concentrate on the important bit; learning process itself.

ResponsesInList.Text: Well, that has one explanation: Your upgrade to "newer" book installed the book capabilities used by the block. When you downgraded it ( option that isn't recommended at all! ), those capabilities continue being there, so the block continues working, although the "older" book doesn't know/use anything about them. So, you can consider yourself as a lucky (really lucky) guy if the older module continues working after having performed one downgrade. Please don't do that ever! Correct approach should be to: 1) install/upgrade new version in test server 2) test, test, test 3) if everything is ok, upgrade real (production) server 4) if there are problems, report them in the Tracker. but, never (and I repeat, never! ) try do downgrade to older versions of Moodle plugins ! Ciao

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading Word Document with images into a book images will not load?
ResponsesInList.Text: Vikki, Perhaps someone else out there knows a better way. The only way I know to import from a Word HTML file is the text and formatting will come through and then there will be shapes with a little icon in them for the images. These shapes then have to be connected to the image file in Moodle.  The Word html type of document that seems to import most easily in the book is the single file web page.  It doesn't have a separate folder of all the images. If I am not the one who created the document, I also save a regular Word web page doc. I find it in the web page/image file, click on it and go through the upload process.  When I save the new address in the image popup window, the image will appear in the editing page of book chapter. It's a little tedious if there are a lot of pictures, but because I have the image names and the image folder to match against, it goes pretty quickly.  I haven't worked with links to out side pictures before, but if the link is there, you probably need to just renew it was well. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I'm new to the Book module, need some advice.
ResponsesInList.Text: This is just a really quick note Marcus, only asking about one thing. Who says all scrolling is bad?  If you are reading, then is it a problem to scroll down? The Scroll of Death typically in Moodle is scrolling to find what you want, constantly, often because the position of the navigation and it's structure is not optimal, or the functionality is not being used (like single section layouts) etc. For example, in this page,  we have nice Menus at the top, but generally, to get to ANY admin function, we need to scroll.  Unless you click to close other menus, in which case you then loose that navigation they provide.  This is the scroll of death.  Scroll is OK in other respects Here is a comment from the wonderful people at 'Adapt': Innovations in design Adapt isn't just a fresh take on an e-learning framework, it also offers an innovative approach to design and course navigation and incorporates, what we think, are several exciting developments: Components instead of templates - pages are constructed by combining a wide range of interactive components in any number and mix required. Removing unnecessary navigation - It makes sense to keep all related content together and to only navigate somewhere new when the content demands it, not when the designer has run out of room on the screen. To make this possible we've implemented a scrolling page layout which leverages much of the latest thinking in web design into the world of e-learning. For example, previous 'sacred cows' of web design such as no content 'below the fold' are now being challenged as we now design for a more web-savvy audience. Preferences - Not sold on scrolling page layouts? No problem, more traditional linear layouts are just as easy to implement. https://community.adaptlearning.org/mod/page/view.php?id=20 I'm not actually sure why you say "I've had to scroll to the bottom of the page . . ." -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I'm new to the Book module, need some advice.
ResponsesInList.Text: Marcus, To add new sub chapter: After the first chapter is created, make sure editing is on and click on the plus after the Chapter title in the Table of contents to get the add new chapter. Click in the check box next to Subchapter right under the title window for the new chapter. Add the information in the Content window. Save this new chapter.  This will create a subchapter that will be connected to the previous chapter. HINT: if you need to create several subchapters under the same chapter, you can click on the plus on the previous subchapter. This will bring up the book chapter creation/edit page with the subchapter already checked, so you don't have to remember each time. If you forgot to check the subchapter box: Just move this chapter right under the chapter which will be the parent chapter Click on the edit symbol next to the chapter you want to become the subchapter. When the chapter edit page comes up, check the box next to the subchapter and save. This should put it under the parent chapter as a subchapter. There are only these two levels to the book module.  You cannot have subchapters of subchapters. Here is more info , including importing chapters from HTML files that might help you if you have a lot of books to create. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim Good to hear you got the file to open in a new window Once you have the plugin URL, you can do exactly the same with any file type that is supported by Moodle Re: Audio I think mp2 is only a sound file. If you want moving pictures with (or without) sound, it has to be an mpeg3, or something similar like a .mov file. Perhaps the thing to do, is practice on a little video clip, that you know works fine (I made one of the washing machine that lasted 10 seconds, but it had sound and some movement) And then I played about with different file-types, compression, file-size, etc. Also, the recording device needs to be set up to capture the best quality available Re: Efficiency Common sense would say, don't make a copy just have a link to your private files. But I think it is also about attaching all the required resources to your book, so that it is self-contained. If at a later stage, you decide to copy the whole thing into another course - or perhaps even share it with another tutor, they might not have access to your private files You might want to consider storing very large files in 'the cloud', maybe Dropbox or Google Drive. But sometimes it good to just push at the boundaries of Moodle to see what it can handle... Have fun...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding caption to a image
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joelias, Over the years I have used numerous ways. Place the caption on the next line of text below a picture. - Can have alignment problems. Place pictures with text in cells of a table. - Can have alignment problems. Add text caption to the picture using a photo editing program such as GIMP. - Caption becomes part of the picture. My favorite is to use Snagit. It costs money but is pretty cheap. It does have a free trial version so you can try it out to see if it does what you want. It has hot keys to bring it up at any time and lets you capture from the screen and does just about anything you want to, to the resulting picture. You can mark on the picture, add a caption, watermark your picture, make fancy edges and borders, etc. HTH , AL

A tip when using Jing (or similar) is to place a blank (Word?) page behind the image on your screen, but sticking out under the image.  That gives you a white space to place your caption on, if you don't want the caption on your actual image. Keith

ResponsesInList.Title: Epub ebook from Book Module?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is to suggest an option for exporting from the Book module in Epub ebook format. This format has been around a few years, but has been getting recent attention due to support annouced for the Apple iPad. Epub format is conceptually similar to the IMS format which the book module can already export to. I managed to turn the book from my Green ICT course into a printed book " Green Technology Strategies ". I then realised I could create a Amazon Kindle format ebook as well, reasonably simply. I discovered that this process does very little to the HTML generated by Moodle. It just changes from one verion of HTML to another, adds some XML housekeeping files and zips the whole lot up in a file. The Epub format appears to be simialr to the Kindle format, but using a different version of HTML and XML different houskeeping files. If you are wondering what this is all about, see my talk notes: " Making e-Books for e-Learning on i-Pads ".

Ordbrand develops the ebook reader Lucifox add-on for Firefox , Luciwik OPDS and LuciwikEPUB for Mediawiki, Nikolay Pultsin develops FBReader for Android phones and tablets, and LibreOffice has a "Send to" Mediawiki function, meaning you can write off-line and upload to your wiki when you are ready. The first warp speed collaborative ebook experience using Ordbrand's extensions is now live at http://far.no/index.php?title=Spesial:Luciwik and details about what you can do is more detailed in my blog at http://friends.gnutelephony.org/display/haakonme/12315 All software mentioned is Free (as in freedom) software under GNU license terms and available at no cost too . With OPDS and EPUB 3 in Moodle, you support open and vendor neutral production, distribution and consumption of books. We can put books in students pockets by hitting "Save".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Formatting Book TOC  issues

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ability to combine books
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marti, You can do what you want in a round-about way like I do. I have a "resource" category with courses where I put all my books organized by subject. I break it up into separate books. I make one book the TOC for all the separate books and link to them via URL's. ResponsesInList.Title: Suggested Method for Restoring Book Content from 1.9 Courses into 2.3
ResponsesInList.Text: Books created in the book module plugin in versions prior to Moodle 2.3 don't remain intact after a site or course has been converted to 2.3. Here is a suggested method for retrieving and restoring book content in a 2.3 course, assuming that both the 1.9 and 2.3 versions of the course are accessible: 1. Create a backup file of just the book content from the 1.9 course 2. Put the backup file in a file repository 3. Restore the file into the appropriate 2.3 course, merging the content 4. Move the book resources in the outline if necessary You could create all of the book backup files prior to upgrading the Moodle site if you don't intend to maintain the 1.9 site separately.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggested Method for Restoring Book Content from 1.9 Courses into 2.3
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is another way. In Moodle 1.9, open the book and click on the Generate IMS content package. Save the zip file it generates on your local computer. (I have a Book backup folder where I keep copies of all of mine.) In Moodle 2.3, create a new book (with the right name) in the course/topic where you want it. After you have named it and are then ready to put text on the first page, click on Import Chapter . In the Import dialog window, click the down arrow for Type and select, Each folder represents one chapter . Then click the Choose a file button and go select the zip file you saved and upload it. Once it is uploaded, click on the Import button. After importing and linking, you will have your new complete book. If your see that each page of the book has two copies of the title, edit the Book and selected, Custom Titles , which will turn one of them off. HTH , AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replace inside custom theme some icons on book module
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Gilles-Philippe, It is possible to override the images from within a theme. You can do so in the following way: 
```text
 



// Original path



mod/book/tool/print/pix/book.png







// Path in theme



theme/mytheme/pix_plugins/booktool/print/book.png
```
 When looking for an overriding image the following path is used. 1. theme (static) 2. themename => mytheme 3. area => pix_plugins for plugin images, pix_core for core images, pix for theme images. 4. plugin type => booktool 5. plugin name => print 6. file name => book It then searches for the image with the following extensions gif, png, jpg, jpeg in that order. Hope this helps. Its not always the easiest thing to work out, I myself had to look at code to remind myself how it all worked. As such I've updated http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Themes_2.0_How_to_use_images_within_your_theme#Overriding_plugin_images with this information as well. Cheers Sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a New Resource or Activity Box To A Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Helen, Moodle does not permit the addition of resources and activities to a Book resource or to a new Moodle page.  I believe a good course design has all assignments and forums available on the front page so they are not hidden or embedded in other objects. However, any resource or activity you create in a course has a web url.  So you can do what you want to do - cross link to an assignment or forum. 1. Create an assignment or forum in the standard manner. 2. Right-click on the link to the assignment or forum and copy the link location.  This usually works - if not, open the assignment or forum and copy the resulting link that appears in your browser address bar. 3. Go to the Book you are creating.  Add text, such as "Upload your assignment here."  Select the text and click on the editor link icon (chain link).  Paste the copied url in the link box. Floyd Saner

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Nedd to have test links within book in groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Bill, A very easy way to accommodate ADA requests like this is to have your sys admin folks create a separate student role (we named ours 'Ignore Time Limits') for which the role setting "Quiz...Ignore Time Limits" is enabled.  Assign the student to that role and the time setting on all exams in that course will be ignored for that student. Floyd Saner

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Nedd to have test links within book in groups
ResponsesInList.Text:
Floyd,

Also in the book format the page is created like a web page and so the "click here" link to the test will only link to the test prepared for the main class since the link goes to a specific Moodle page I.D number. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need to have test links within book in groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Bill, Ah, the two different time limits present a problem.  I'm quite certain there is no way to set a separate time limit when 'ignore time limits' is enabled for a role. Using Groups does not solve the problem either because both groups still see the same exam.  The only thing Groups will do for a quiz activity is allow the teacher to view the group results separately. The real (but complicated) solution to this is to use Groupings of Groups.  Then you create two different quiz activities (each with a different time limit), but each grouping will see only one quiz - the quiz for their grouping.  You still have the problem of the book link to the quiz.  To make this really work, you would then have to create two books, one for each grouping, with a link to the appropriate quiz activity. Groupings of Groups is very powerful, but can get a little messy.  I've used it for a music course that had Men's Chorus, Women's Chorus and Mixed Choir.  We were able to tailor what each student could see in the course by creating various Groupings of the three groups. It will be interesting to see if anyone else has a suggestion. Floyd

ResponsesInList.Text: A. I loose the layout of chapters while printing in the Moodle Book module for version 1.9.7. Some bolds disappear for example, or solid lines with tables. On screen they stay visible. Is this something I can prevent? B. Also, when editing text in the html editor and then saving, unexpected layout changes appear. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Layout loss in Moodle Book print function
ResponsesInList.Text: We experienced something similar. The HTML editor in Moodle allows the use of <font> tags, but there is a stylesheet applied to the book that overrides all <font> declarations. If you have access to your Moodle code, have a look at /mod/book/book_print. css I reproduce the relevant section here: /* just some hack - ignore user defined <font> */ font { color: #000000; background-color: #EEEEEE; font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif; This is obviously frustrating for users who do want to specify styles in the HTML editor. Essentially, the HTML editor ceases to be WYSIWYG , because your changes are overridden by the stylesheet. If you're confident with CSS, you can remove sections (or just comment them out using /* to mark the beginning of the block you want ignored, and */ to mark its end). Alternatively, you can rename book_print.css and create a new, empty file named book_print.css. I haven't tried this, so it might make more of a pig's breakfast of the layout, but at least your styling choices will not be ignored.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi is there anyway of importing a PDF document with chapters etc in it into a book resource effectively keeping the same format without having to copy individual sections manually? Thanks Rob

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Book resource from PDF
ResponsesInList.Text: Well you can screen shot each page and upload it that way but I am not familiar with a more elegant solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Book resource from PDF
ResponsesInList.Text: Rob Cunniffe asked Wednesday, 10 March 2010, 04:14 AM: >Hi is there anyway of importing a PDF document with chapters etc in it into a book resource ... There is no easy way to import PDF into a Moodle Book. You can try a PDF to HTML conversion tool (such as the one provided by Adobe ). But the results are usually disappointing. Most documents created with PDF do not have the needed formatting information in them to create a good web page. Even where there is formatting, it is very poor and does not suit online viewing of the document. The good news is that it is very easy to convert from a Moodle Book to PDF and to other formats such as ebooks. I spend a lot of time copying the text from PDF documents into web pages for my Green Technology Strategies course. But then I was able to produce a Moodle Book and from that publish a printed book and ebook. My hope is that ebook formats with better formatting will one day replace PDF.

ResponsesInList.Text: The trick I use is to export the books as IMS objects, it's basically html. Reconstituting the book is slightly easier. Graphics still have to be handled manually. IMS is also usable as a object it imports straight into Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issues creating books using HTML
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kathi, We also have Moodle 1.9, and when you open the book with editing turned on, so you can see the TOC, there is a link at the top that says import. (You have to first create ONE page which becomes the title page for your book, if you are creating a new book. Make it a simple title with limited html.) You can import a folder and it will automatically bring in all html files in that folder.  Therefore you can upload all your html files into one folder and easily import them to your book, maintaining all the style sheet links. I always choose to import my folder as subchapters which makes it easy to delete all pages at once if I want to re-import.  If you are creating a new book every month you might not need to do this. You're right, once you edit a page in moodle it strips off all the headers and so removes the css links.  I try to never edit the files directly in the moodle editor.  Myself, I reimport the entire book if I change one page so my .css stays active.  I always upload the corrected html file to the folder for import.  OR you could import just the one changed page, and then use the arrows to position it after deleting the old page. Nancy

ResponsesInList.Title: Using a Lesson to simulate a Book
ResponsesInList.Text: I have used the Book module in the past, but because of upgrading issues, I decided to try Lesson as a substitute. There are obviously some things you can do with Book that you can't do with Lesson (e.g., import pages), but unless you really need these things, maybe you should consider using Lesson, since it is a core module -- at least it was the last time I checked . Here are the Lesson settings I use: Slideshow mode = Yes Display left menu = Yes Make every page a Branch table with Description 1 = "Previous" and Jump 1 = Previous page Description 2 = "Next" and Jump 2 = Next page. This will display an index on the left (allowing direct access to any page) and two buttons at the bottom of the page (allowing the reader to move forward or back by one page).

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Kenji, If you configure Moodle in order to display blocks in the module pages, you'll see that you can add a web link to your Lesson: Site administration -> Appearence -> Themes -> Theme settings -> In the right side of the screen, activate the option "Show blocks on module pages". (this path is for Moodle 1.9-3+, in other versions it may vary) With this feature on, you can add an HTML block, with a link to a PDF file with all the content of your "Lesson Book" (if this term is allowed ). If you insert a small icon of a printer and you add the web link to it, you'll almost have the same effect that in the Book module. Well, just an idea ...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Sound importing utility to the Book module?
ResponsesInList.Text: Nora, There are two ways to upload your sound files. You can create them in something like audacity and save them as mp3 files and then go to the files link in your administration block and create a folder called audio_files or something like that and then upload the files there. The other option is to start a book chapter and then highlight a word and click on the link button and then browse. From here you can create folders and upload files to the same area as before. Once you have the files uploaded you have two options: 1) create a link to the audio file that you want and then when the student clicks on the word the default player for that audio type will load and the student can listen to the file. The other way is to turn on the media filter in the modules->filters->manage filters area of your site. This will add an embedded player that students can just click on. See the attached graphic. It may not be exactly what you are looking for but it works great. If you have questions please ask away.

In trying to understand the details of this software, however, I find that I am getting a bit lost in all the detail. I submit a plea for your help to get me over this hump. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bonehead question from a newbie...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tom, I don't think the limitation for what you want to do in Moodle for your students is within Moodle itself. Moodle is a browser based web application so you would need to scout out some of the technologies developed over the past 25 years for computer assistance. In 1984 I produced a training video for the University of Virgina on a retinal scan camera device that was fairly non-intrusive, which allowed someone with CP to easily move a cursor around the screen by simply looking at what they wanted to do and blinking for click. I'm sure this technology has evolved considerably but I've not kept up with it. I have seen special trackballs and a few other gizmo's. Try Googling computer devices for accessibility etc. Your students at www.hischopsticks.org look like some of my wifes students.... the faces of angels! I've often wondered what the response would be to introducing this student population to virtual environments like SecondLife, where they could experience a sense of greater mobility while learning. Would they find this interesting?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Book import fixes
ResponsesInList.Text: I found the answer to my question. According to the Moodle documentation on non-standard modules, Some of the modules may contain their own language files. If so then just leave them there, they'll be found automatically. Book is one of the modules that 'contains its own language files' (contrib/plugins/mod/book/lang). There is no need to move this directory (or merge it with moodle/lang) because Moodle looks for a mod/book/lang directory before looking for moodle/lang/book. The CVS checkout command for book, and later the CVS update command, are all that's needed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Book module in 1.6
ResponsesInList.Text: Simply deleteing via the modules I/F and removing the tables does NOT solve this problem. At least, it didn't for me. I had the same error message about "(mysql): INSERT INTO mdl_log_display (module, action, mtable, field) VALUES ('bookmark', 'update', 'bookmark', 'name') " that the above user had. The system is trying to add records to the mdl_log_display table that are already there. You need to remove them manually. Login to mysql and run the following to delete the tables and remove the offending keys; drop table mdl_book; drop table mdl_book_chapters; delete from mdl_log_display where module = 'book'; That should remove two tables and 4 entries from the mdl_log_display fields. If you are using php_my_admin, login normally and look for "book" in the field "module" of table "mdl_log_display." Delete the 4 records the system finds. HIH, Kevin Metcalf

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone Know How to Change "Table of Contents" copy?
ResponsesInList.Text: The answer depends on what version of Moodle you're using. In 1.6, login as administrator, go to the front page of your site. In the Administration block, click Admin -> Configuration -> Language. You will see 3 links, including "Edit strings". Clicking "Edit strings" will show you the complete list of language files. In this case, the string is in the " book .php" file, so you have to click on that to get the list of strings for that file. Scrolling down you'll see "Table of Contents" on the left, and to the right you should be able to type whatever you want to change it to. Hit the save button at the bottom of the page. In later versions of Moodle, the menus have changed, so it may be a little different. Look for it -- you'll find it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PDF Protection and Access rights
ResponsesInList.Text: PDF's by definition are "Portable" documents. I'm not aware of any way that the content provider can control further re-distribution. If there is a way to do this, it is going to be in the way that the PDF is created/encrypted/passworded. You can create PDF's that are protected so that the text and image can't be extracted (i.e. cut and pasted) but its fairly easy to beat those limitations. But again the PDF format is designed to allow the document to be freely shared while providing a consistent appearance (fonts, page layout) and some degree of protection against alteration of the document. It's almost impossible to insure that anything available on the internet can't be captured and sent on to others. If I am interpreting your request correctly you want to have some form of DRM on the text files. You may want to research some forms of Document DRM or MicroSoft iDRM. In terms of MOODLE you are asking it serve in manner completely contrary to it's design. The social constructionist philosophy says share everything and see what happens, it's usually good. MOODLE does have the ability to restrict files to selected groups of users (think classes and/or groups) so you can post a file that only some users can access, but has no ability to determine what they do with the file once they have it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation Problem?
ResponsesInList.Text: John, Assume that you are using moodle in english and therefore will assume the language file to be en. The same reasoning would apply to other languages as well. Instances where you see things like modulename are indicative of language file problem. It means generally that it is not UTF8 compliant. The way to address that in most cases is to copy the language file in the block or module you are installing into your language file en_utf8 directory. Some modules have an en_utf in which case copying the lang directory in the module you are installing to the lang directory in moodle will take care of things. But there are modules where developers have not adhered to this rule yet and have only en directory in the language file. In that case, you have to copy manually from en directory in the module to en_utf8. The proviso is that the developers have made the module UTF compliant even if they don't have an en_utf directory in the plugin. I have not installed the book module. It could well be that what I am saying here doesn't work for this module. Juvenal.

ResponsesInList.Text: Petr, Chardelle's "resource toolbar" is very similar to the "Action Menubar" found in WebCT Campus Edition Content Modules and WebCT Vista Learning Modules. The Action Menubar has been around since the beginningof WebCT. A Moodle Resource Toolbar (WebCT Action Menubar) is a way to provide resources that support the content but are not required to be in the linear sequence of reading the content. For example, I might have some content that includes some URLs of additional information on another web site. In the content, there might even be a "see the links in the resource toolbar for further information". A few common component in the past has been self-tests, glossaries and student notes. Quizzes are another component that can be placed either in sequence of the module or on the toolbar of a page. If the quiz is optional so the student can improve learning, then it goes on the toolbar of the page. But if I want the student to take the quiz after reading the content, then it goes on the "next page" after the content so there is a better chance of not missing it. Resource toolbar is a good way to provide extras while keeping the student on a particular page. Cheers, Bob

ResponsesInList.Text: Now that there is a stable release of the book module,  I just installed it on my Moodle. In doing so, I have come up with a satisfactory (but not perfect) answer to the question that I posted at the beginning of this thread, and I wanted to share it with others who might be interested in doing something similar. Here's what I would do. I'll be working in topics format, with each topic corresponding to a chapter in an offline textbook that the students will be using in my course. I am creating a set of my own notes (my book)  to accompany this textbook, with a chapter in my book corresponding to each chapter in the offline book. I will put the book itself into the topic outline. If  people click on it there, they will be taken to an introductory chapter that explains the purpose of the book. Then in each of the topics, I will create a resource. I will make its type "web link," and link to the page for the relevant chapter in the book. Why is this solution not perfect? Two reasons come to mind: The fact that the icons used for book and resource differ may confuse people (although in my Moodle this won't be an issue because I am using the same hieroglyphic icon for both activities). If someone clicks on the resources link in the activities block, they will see all of the individual chapters listed. If they click on the books link they will see the whole book. A work around for this would be to hide the activities block altogether. In some cases, this might be OK because there would be no need to see all the activities grouped in that manner, but it would depend on the individual needs of the course. I want to give my thanks to Petr for this great module. I especially like the printing function of it. I am sure I will be using this module A LOT in my courses.
